title: 106_s796
content: The Act titled "Mental Health Equitable Treatment Act of 1999" is cited in Section 1. Section 2 includes amendments to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is amended to include hospital day and outpatient visit limits for group health plans providing medical, surgical, and mental health benefits. No inpatient limits are allowed for mental health benefits if there is no limit for medical and surgical benefits. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 now includes limits on inpatient and outpatient visits for group health plans offering medical, surgical, and mental health benefits. Inpatient limits for mental health benefits must be comparable to those for medical and surgical benefits, while no outpatient visit limits are allowed for mental health benefits if none exist for medical and surgical benefits. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 sets limits on outpatient visits for mental health benefits that must be comparable to those for medical and surgical benefits. No limitations are allowed for severe biologically-based mental illnesses unless similar limitations exist for medical and surgical benefits. The section does not require group health plans to provide mental health benefits or change the terms of existing mental health benefits, except for specific parity requirements outlined in subsection (a). The section outlines specific parity requirements for mental health benefits, including annual limits and inpatient/outpatient visit limits. It also allows qualified health professionals to provide care within their scope of practice. The section outlines specific parity requirements for mental health benefits, including annual limits and inpatient/outpatient visit limits. It also allows qualified health professionals to provide care within their scope of practice. The term 'severe biologically-based mental illness' is defined as an illness. The section outlines parity requirements for mental health benefits, including limits on visits and qualified professionals providing care within their scope. The term 'severe biologically-based mental illness' is defined as an illness affirmed by medical science and the DSM IV, including schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, major depression, and other severe mental disorders. Amendments apply to plan years starting on or after January 1, 2000. Amendments to the Public Health Service Act regarding the group market. Amendments to the Public Health Service Act (42 U.S.C. 300gg-5) now include provisions for group health plans to not impose limits on inpatient hospital stays for mental health benefits if there are no limits for medical and surgical benefits. The Public Health Service Act now prohibits group health plans from imposing limits on inpatient hospital stays for mental health benefits if there are no limits for medical and surgical benefits. Additionally, if there are no limits on outpatient visits for medical and surgical benefits, the plan cannot impose any limits on outpatient visits for mental health benefits. The Public Health Service Act prohibits group health plans from imposing limits on outpatient visits for mental health benefits if there are no limits for medical and surgical benefits. Additionally, plans cannot impose limitations on benefits for severe biologically-based mental illnesses unless comparable limitations are imposed on medical and surgical benefits. The Public Health Service Act prohibits group health plans from imposing limits on mental health benefits, including outpatient visits, without imposing similar limits on medical and surgical benefits. This applies to the terms and conditions of mental health benefits under the plan or coverage. The Public Health Service Act prohibits group health plans from imposing limits on mental health benefits. Qualified health professionals can provide care and treatment for mental health services within their scope of practice. The act exempts small employers with 2 to 25 employees from certain requirements. The term "severe biologically-based mental illness" is defined in the act. The Public Health Service Act defines "severe biologically-based mental illness" as a condition affirmed by medical science and the DSM IV, including schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, major depression, and other severe mental disorders. The amendments made by this section apply to plan years starting on or after January 1, 2000. SEC. 4. PREEMPTION. State laws providing greater protections to enrollees than those under the amendments made by this Act are not preempted.
